exemplars.name: Charlie Munger
exemplars.track_record: Vice Chairman of Berkshire Hathaway; legendary investor; built $700+ billion company with Warren Buffett; known for contrarian thinking
exemplars.constraints: Operated with long-term perspective; avoided herd mentality; emphasized mental models and rational thinking over emotional decisions
notable_actions: Consistently challenged conventional wisdom in investing and business
Developed 'inversion' technique - thinking backwards to identify failure modes
Advocated for 'sit and wait' strategy rather than constant action
Used multiple mental models from various disciplines to challenge assumptions
Famously said 'I never allow myself to have an opinion on anything that I don't know the other side's argument better than they do'

exemplars.name: Daniel Kahneman
exemplars.track_record: Nobel Prize winner in Economics; pioneered behavioral economics; author of 'Thinking, Fast and Slow'; transformed understanding of human decision-making
exemplars.constraints: Challenged the assumption of rational economic actors; faced academic resistance to behavioral approach; had to prove cognitive biases through extensive research
notable_actions: Identified and documented systematic cognitive biases that challenge rational decision-making
Developed prospect theory showing how people make decisions under risk
Challenged economic orthodoxy by demonstrating predictable irrationality
Showed how overconfidence and confirmation bias lead to poor decisions
Advocated for 'thinking slow' to counteract fast, intuitive errors

exemplars.name: Nassim Taleb
exemplars.track_record: Mathematical statistician; former options trader; author of 'The Black Swan'; predicted 2008 financial crisis; scholar at risk engineering
exemplars.constraints: Operated outside academic mainstream; challenged established risk models; faced skepticism from traditional finance and statistics communities
notable_actions: Identified 'black swan' events - rare, unpredictable, high-impact occurrences
Challenged Value at Risk (VaR) models used by major financial institutions
Advocated for 'antifragility' - systems that gain from disorder and stress
Criticized over-reliance on Gaussian distributions and normal curve assumptions
Demonstrated how financial models underestimate tail risks and extreme events
